title: George Ayscue
text:
Sir George Ayscue (c. 1616 – 5 April 1672) was an English naval officer who served in the <a href="English%20Civil%20War">English Civil War</a> and the <a href="Anglo-Dutch%20Wars">Anglo-Dutch Wars</a> who rose to the rank of <a href="Admiral%20of%20the%20white">Admiral of the White</a>. He also served as Governor of Scilly Isles (1647) and <a href="Governor%20of%20Barbados">Governor of Barbados</a> (1650–1652).
Biography.
Ayscue (sometimes, erroneously, Askew or Ayscough) came from an old <a href="Lincolnshire">Lincolnshire</a> family, and was <a href="knight">knight</a>ed by <a href="Charles%20I%20of%20England">Charles I</a> on 9 August 1641. In 1646 he received a naval command, In August 1647 he was appointed Governor of <a href="Scilly%20Isles">Scilly Isles</a> a post he held until January 1647. In July 1648, during the <a href="English%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a>, while serving as a captain in the navy of the English Parliament, he was recognized as restoring sailors' allegiances at sea and later in the year given command of two vessels and promoted to <a href="Rear%20Admiral">Rear Admiral</a>. In 1649 he was appointed <a href="Irish%20Squadron%20%28Royal%20Navy%29">Admiral of the Irish Seas</a>. In 1650 Ayscue was appointed Governor of <a href="Barbados">Barbados</a> and Commander of the squadron sent to the island. In 1651 he served with General at Sea <a href="Robert%20Blake%20%28admiral%29">Robert Blake</a> in the capture of the <a href="Isles%20of%20Scilly">Scilly Isles</a> from Sir <a href="John%20Granville%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Bath">John Granville, 1st Earl of Bath</a>. Later that year he captured <a href="Barbados">Barbados</a> from <a href="Francis%20Willoughby%2C%205th%20Baron%20Willoughby%20of%20Parham">Lord Willoughby</a> and the other English colonies in the Americas. In the <a href="First%20Anglo-Dutch%20War">First Anglo-Dutch War</a> he was defeated by the Dutch Commodore <a href="Michiel%20de%20Ruyter">Michiel de Ruyter</a> at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Plymouth">Battle of Plymouth</a>. Relieved of his command, he went into service in the Swedish Navy, returning after the <a href="English%20Restoration">Restoration</a> of <a href="Charles%20II%20of%20England">Charles II</a>. In 1664 he was appointed <a href="Rear-Admiral%20of%20the%20Blue">Rear-Admiral of the Blue Squadron</a>. In June 1665 he was appointed <a href="Vice-Admiral%20of%20the%20Blue">Vice-Admiral of the Blue</a>. During the <a href="Second%20Anglo-Dutch%20War">Second Anglo-Dutch War</a> he commanded a squadron at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Lowestoft">Battle of Lowestoft</a> in 1665.
In February 1666 he was appointed <a href="Admiral%20of%20the%20Blue">Admiral of the Blue</a> and at the start of the <a href="Four%20Days%27%20Battle">Four Days' Battle</a> in June 1666 he was elevated to the rank of <a href="Admiral%20of%20the%20white">Admiral of the White</a>, his flagship, , <a href="Ship%20grounding">ran aground</a> on the Galloper Shoal and he was forced to surrender his ship to <a href="Lieutenant-Admiral">Lieutenant-Admiral</a> <a href="Cornelis%20Tromp">Cornelis Tromp</a>, earning the unfortunate distinction of being the highest-ranking English naval officer to have been captured by the enemy. He was held prisoner during the war in the Dutch state prison of <a href="Loevestein">Loevestein</a>, and almost certainly never again took to sea as admiral. In December 1671, he was the President of the Court Martial of Rear-Admiral Sir William Jennings, held on board . Sir George Ayscue was still a serving officer when he died at his <a href="Westminster%2C%20London">Westminster</a> house on 5 April 1672. His burial was held on 13 April 1672 <a href="St%20Margaret%27s%20Church%2C%20Westminster">St Margaret's Church, Westminster</a>, London, England.
